text: this week's movies visited grim crystal
fairy and fruitvale station south fire
prepare fruitvale station is about a
real life incident the shooting of Oscar
Grant in the back by a bay area rapid
transit police officer in his review aO
Scott writes the film examines its
subject with a steady objective eye and
tells his story in the key of wise
heartbreak rather than blind rage
everything it has to say about class
masculinity is embedded in details of
character in place the film's great
achievement is to make Oscar of fully
human presence to pay him the respect of
acknowledging his complexities and
contradictions the radicalism of
fruitvale station lies precisely here in
its refusal to turn a man into a symbol
I'll see you when you get home get my
whole dog get a hug mom ran walking by
the visiting area go now I'm sorry hey
you mom sorry Abby's gonna hook my my
limits get home up in bham sorry this is
the perfect thing in my life right now
like to do this to do mescaline crystal
fairy follows two young Americans on a
drug-fueled road trip at three Chilean
brothers in his review Stephen Holden
writes movie is so deceptively easy
going that it feels semi-improvised by
the actors who include the directors
three brothers crystal Harry why are you
making you like crystal Harry Alan
crystal Harry that's good the seeming
casualness is such that at a certain
point you feel like a traveler on a real
life journey crystal fairy is the
furthest thing from a conventional trip
movie its last part portrays the group
drug experience with minimal psychedelic
effects only some subtly glowing colors
and muted actors
we've chosen to believe
today we face the monsters in our door
today we are canceling the apocalypse in
Pacific Rim Guillermo del Toro's new
movie manned robots fight to save the
earth from an alien invasion in his
review AO scott rights for all a talk of
neural drift dimensional wormholes this
world is filled with tubes and rivets
and pistons the pleasures of Pacific Rim
are somewhat nostalgic and maybe also
regressive I need to access a kaiju
brain completely intact this summer
cinematic offerings have so far largely
been a parade of joyless Bob mast in
these circumstances mr. del Toro's
exuberant nonsense comes as a relief
